What we eat has an effect on the environment.

author: Carbon Conversations

This is the greenhouse effect. John Tyndall, an Irish physicist, discovered and described it in 1859, building on the work of French physicist Joseph Fourier three decades earlier, and the mostly uncredited (at the time) of Eunice Foote in 1856.
The science of global warming goes back a long way.

The sun isn't the problem - destruction of our atmosphere is the problem.

author: Michael Tobis (mt)
text:
Um, basically no. 

The atmosphere and ocean equilibrate rapidly. In the large, any added vapour is balanced by suppressing evaporation.

The biggest exception is ‚Äúcorn sweat‚Äù. Large hot irrigated areas  can exacerbate humidity and greenhouse forcing locally. But the global effect is very small.

‚ÄúThe existence of the greenhouse effect was proposed as early as 1824 by Joseph Fourier.‚Äù

‚ÄúLate 1900s
Svante Arrhenius and others began to explore the idea that human activities, like the burning of fossil fuels, could increase the concentration of greenhouse gases and might lead to warming.‚Äù

In 1903 (yes, 1903) Svante August Arrhenius won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work identifying the carbon dioxide greenhouse effect. Climate change due to greenhouse gases is well established. Trump and his elderly ilk don't care about the world after they're dead.

(14/n) Local action to restore of #rivers, #lakes & #wetlands is critically important for lots of reasons.

ENDS.

author: Dave Tickner
text:
(6/n) We reviewed 16 science articles that analysed causes of freshwater biodiversity loss globally.

None of them systematically assessed these underlying socio-economic drivers.

Few explicitly linked biodiversity trends & changes in national/international policies or business behaviour.

1. Changing stress on faults
Melting Glaciers and Ice Sheets: The immense weight of glaciers and ice sheets exerts pressure on the Earth's crust beneath them. As these masses melt due to climate change, the crust experiences a release of pressure, a process known as isostatic rebound.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text:
I'll also reiterate that electricity is only a bit over a fifth of global primary energy consumption.

(Be cautious of higher numbers in forecasts for 2030 because they're commonly for "data centres", but remember that most data centre power is actually crypto)

Renewables generated the equivalent of 113% of our electricity consumption, but electricity is only about 20%of our energy consumption. The other 80% is domestic or commercial use of gas, plus domestic oil, and petrol and diesel in vehicles.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text: *** - "... responsible for 1,5% of global final energy consumption *growth*."

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text: Even when represented as share of *growth*, not total energy, it's small.  And furthermore, I see no reason to represent it as a share of growth. It's total energy consumption that matters.  Nothing is static - not datacentre consumption, not *any* consumption.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text:
So datacentres - again, which are mostly Bitcoin -  are responsible for ~4% of global electricity growth.

Electricity is about 1/5th of final energy consumption, and global energy grew by 2,2%, so datacentre growth is responsible for 1,5% of global final energy consumption.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text: In 2024, datacentres were 1,5% of global electricity (not energy) consumption, with an annual growth rate of ~12% since 2017. Again, by far mostly Bitcoin, not AI, but let's ignore that. That's 0,18% electricity growth per year from datacentres.  Global electricity demand increased by 4,3% in 2024.

Current Policies Scenario (CPS)

Oil and gas demand do not peak.
